abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome was unsatisfactory,
            with modest institutional development impacts. Nonetheless,
            sustainability is likely, based on an apparently, continual
            commitment by the Government, in using the improved
            watershed methodologies, developed under the project,
            despite the need for stronger economic returns to
            investments in projects like this one. Both performances
            were also rated unsatisfactory; the Bank failed to provide
            adequate supervision, and, the Borrower failed to follow up
            preparation, and implementation with a detailed project
            plan, and training program to prepare the implementing
            agencies with the project work. Lessons reinforce the need
            for government commitments in results-oriented,
            demand-driven projects, as well as stakeholders'
            involvement in planning project activities, such as
            conservation, and village infrastructure works, to attain
            the expected project development. Yet, and although quality
            at entry is considered partially satisfactory, based on a
            good project design responsive to government priorities for
            promoting sustainable land use systems, certain activities,
            such as preparation of the implementation plan, and the
            bidding process for selection of consultants, should be
            correctly sequenced, started prior to loan effectiveness.
            Furthermore, the weak monitoring and evaluation,
            particularly regarding socioeconomic aspects, was a lost
            opportunity to assess project interventions; and,
            complementary farm activities should increase incomes, e.g.,
            livestock production becomes an effective complement to crop production.
